data.name: HTML DOM: Part 2 - Attributes
data.description:
Your task is to create a simple DOM object, based on the one found in browsers. Create an instantiatible object, `DOM`, and give it the methods below. *This is part 2 of the HTML DOM series.* [Part 1 - Tree](http://www.codewars.com/kata/5b3cd4e72f4b20e09600018b) > NOTE: No features beyond those listed below will be tested, including edge cases. There is a naive implementation provided to get you started for this kata. Though you may copy across code you've made in other parts of this series to expand its functionality if you wish. > There are summaries below, but for more information on how these features work in the browser, check out the [MDN](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Element) page. > Note that while this spec is based on the way the browser's DOM works, not all methods are tested, and not all features are tested. The spec for a complete DOM is very extensive, and would take a long time to fully test and fully pass. These katas are intended to give you an idea of how different effects might be achieved, rather than build a feature-complete virtual DOM. Though if you're having fun making this, you can always carry on to add more features from the spec. # .createElement(tag) Returns a new HTML element node with the specified tag. Each node should have the features outlined below. ## node.attributes A special object that lets you see the attributes attached to the node, without being able to affect it directly. (There are other methods that allow you to add or remove attributes.) The values accessed using .attributes are "live," always up-to-date. > Note that all attribute names should be used as lowercase. ### node.attributes.item(index) Returns the attribute object at the specified index--though the order of the attributes are not necessarily in any particular order (you can implement how the order works however you wish). Each attribute object has two properties: - "name": The name of the attribute. - "value": The value of the attribute. ```javascript // span.attributes.item(0) == { name: "title", value: "this is the span" } ``` ### node.attributes.length How many attributes there are attached to the node. ```javascript // input.attributes.length === 2 ``` ## node.setAttribute(name, value) Sets the value of an existing attribute with the specified name, or adds a new attribute with the specified name and value. ```javascript // input.setAttribute("type", "text"); // input.setAttribute("name", "address1"); // ``` ## node.removeAttribute(name) Removes the attribute with the specified name, is there is one attached to the node. ```javascript // input.removeAttribute("type"); // ``` ## node.getAttribute(name) Returns the value of the attribute with the specified name. If there is no matching attribute, returns `null`. ```javascript // input.getAttribute("name") === "address1" input.getAttribute("tabindex") === null ``` ## node.id This is a special property that is tied to the attribute "id". Its value defaults to an empty string. If the value of one is changed, the value of the other will reflect that change. If there is no attribute and the property's value is set, a new "id" attribute will be added. If the attribute is removed, the property's value is reset to default. ```javascript //
div.id === "" div.getAttribute("id") === null div.id = "main"; //
div.getAttribute("id") === "main" div.removeAttribute("id"); //
div.id === "" div.getAttribute("id") === null ``` ## node.className This is a special property that is tied to the attribue "class". Its value defaults to an empty string. If the value of one is changed, the value of the other will reflect that change. If there is no attribute and the property's value is set, a new "class" attribute will be added. If the attribute is removed, the property's value is reset to default. ```javascript //
div.className === "" div.getAttribute("class") === null div.className = "author heading"; //
div.getAttribute("class") === "author heading" div.removeAttribute("class"); //
div.className === "" div.getAttribute("class") === null ``` ## node.classList This is a special object that is tied to the .className property and "class" attribute. It allows the access and manipulation of individual classes (consecutive non-whitespace characters) within the property, using the properties below. ### node.classList.item(index) Returns the class found in the curent .className or "class" value (a class nearer the start of the value will have a lower index). ```javascript //
div.classList.item(1) === "heading" ``` ### node.classList.add(class1, class2, ...) Accepts any number of classes as arguments. For each class *not already in the .className and "class" values*, they are added to the values. ```javascript //
div.classList.add("heading", "new-class", "author"); div.className === "author heading new-class"; ``` ### node.classList.remove(class1, class2, ...) Accepts any number of classes as arguments. They are each removed from the .className and "class" values, if found. ```javascript //
div.classList.remove("author", "new-class"); div.className === "heading"; ``` ### node.classList.length The number of individual classes found in the current .className or "class" value.
